title: The MOUSE model of autism
description:
When you read about autism research in the media, you may not realise that a lot of this research is actually conducted on mice. In this video I'm going to be deconstructing the so-called "Mouse Model of Autism".

REFERENCES üìÑ
SciTechDaily article: https://scitechdaily.com/a-drug-that-cures-autism-neuroscience-study-yields-promising-results/
Original study: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41380-023-01959-7
Types of autistic mouse behaviour: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3087436/
Why studying autism in mice may be doomed to fail: https://www.spectrumnews.org/features/deep-dive/why-studying-autism-in-mice-may-be-doomed-to-fail/

LINKS üîó
Autistic traits workbook: https://mybook.to/thinkyoureautistic
Sign up for free e-mails and fun: https://www.subscribepage.com/yosamdysam
Tip jar: https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam

TIMESTAMPS ‚åö
00:00 Intro
01:18 The Mouse Model of Autism
05:28 Scientific Validity
06:49 So-called "autistic" behaviours in mice
09:15 How did this gain legitimacy?
10:17 The recent study
14:43 Bloopers

title: No, I don't "look" autistic (BUT...)
description:
Many autistic people often hear the microaggression "you don't look autistic" after disclosing their condition to friends, family or co-workers. Let's dive a little deeper into this idea of what autism "looks" like.

tags: ['book launch party']
title: Book launch party!
description:
So You Think You‚Äôre Autistic (A workbook for the confused person who‚Äôs just trying to figure things out) is a workbook aimed at those seeking clarity around their autistic traits.

When you first come to the realisation that - gasp! - you might be autistic, it‚Äôs a really confusing and lonely time, and there‚Äôs not much guidance out there for what to do next.

This workbook aims to hold your hand (metaphorically) and prompt you to think about areas of your life which are relevant to an autism diagnosis, talk you through some of the diagnostic criteria in an easy to understand way, help you think about masking, imposter syndrome and how to talk to other people about all this.

This book won‚Äôt diagnose you. But it will help you gain more clarity around your autistic traits, and leave you better prepared for your assessment (if you choose to pursue one), and develop more understanding and compassion towards yourself.

It is available on the following international Amazon marketplaces:

US: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
UK: https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Canada: https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Australia: https://www.amazon.com.au/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Germany: https://www.amazon.de/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
France: https://www.amazon.fr/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Spain: https://www.amazon.es/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Italy: https://www.amazon.it/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Netherlands: https://www.amazon.nl/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Poland: https://www.amazon.pl/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Sweden: https://www.amazon.se/dp/B0BMHPLXK2
Japan: https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0BMHPLXK2

title: Reading my old school reports (autistic, ADHD, gifted)
description:
Since looking back at your childhood is a key part of an adult autism assessment, I thought I'd look back at what my teachers said about me, an undiagnosed autistic, ADHD kid with academic giftedness.

My workbook, "So you think you're autistic" is available now!
https://mybook.to/thinkyoureautistic

If you like my content and just want to buy me a virtual coffee ‚òï to support my work, you can buy me a Ko-Fi here: https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam (no longer accepting video commissions)

tags: ['difference between adhd and autism', 'adhd and autism', 'signs of autism', 'autism vs adhd', 'autism or adhd', 'do i have adhd', 'autism and adhd together']
title: 5 signs you have ADHD and autism
description:
In this video, I talk about what it's like having both autism and ADHD and how this can feel from an inner perspective. ADHD and autism have many similarities, but also many conflicting traits, so this can be really difficult to unpick sometimes.

My workbook, "So you think you're autistic" is available now!
https://mybook.to/thinkyoureautistic

title: Being an autistic teenager was hell (it got better)
description:
Being an autistic teenager (and undiagnosed at that!) was extremely isolating and I wanted to share my story in case it helps anyone.

Obviously, I'm not speaking for all autistic people - as we all have unique strengths, difficulties and struggles.

title: EMDR: the weirdest therapy I've ever had
description:
After experiencing EMDR therapy, I knew I had to do a video about my experiences, because it's a very weird, very effective sort of therapy. EMDR is typically used to treat PTSD and trauma but is increasingly being used for other mental health issues.

MERCH! https://yo-samdy-sam.creator-spring.com/

Want to buy me a virtual coffee ‚òï to support my work? https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam (no longer accepting video commissions)

description:
The concept of the autistic spectrum (or the autism spectrum) is largely used but seems poorly understood by people in general. In this video I explain how it came about and what it actually means.

title: How to identify manipulation - and what to do about it
description:
Do you want to avoid manipulation in relationships? Or manipulation at work? Do you want to learn more about how to stop a manipulator? And learn how manipulation and autism can crossover? 

In this video, I take you through what manipulation is, what are the signs of manipulation, why autistic people can be accused of manipulation and are more vulnerable to being manipulated and what you can do about it!

Calming the Chaos: a new monthly course for building emotional and relationship skills*:
UK based people: https://calmingthechaos.teachery.co/ctcuk?a=rrFTHLmj
EU based people: https://calmingthechaos.teachery.co/ctceu?a=rrFTHLmj
US based people: https://calmingthechaos.teachery.co/ctcus?a=rrFTHLmj

title: My Brain Story (Draw Along With Me)
description:
This is a DRAW ALONG WITH ME video! I will be attempting to visually represent how my brain feels on the inside, and I invite you to do the same.

To find out more about the exercise please visit the Neuroclastic website here: https://neuroclastic.com/show-us-your-brain-free-resource-for-understanding-your-brain-story/

The idea is that you download a PDF version of this exercise and either print it off or draw on it digitally. Then we compare our brains!

Download PDF in white with black icons: https://neuroclastic.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Brain-Story-Worksheet8.pdf

Download PDF in black with white icons: https://neuroclastic.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Brain-Story-Worksheet9.pdf

Tag me and Neuroclastic (@Neuroclastic) on Twitter or Instagram and use the hashtag #BrainStory.

Captions are on the way!

tags: ['autism in girls', 'autism symptoms in girls', 'autism traits girls', 'autism in women', 'female autism symptoms', 'female autism traits', 'yo samdy sam', 'yo samedy sam', 'yo sammy sam', 'autistic girls', 'autistic women', 'signs of autism in girls', 'female autism', 'autistic spectrum', 'autism in females', 'autism in girls symptoms']
title: Autism in girls - I was wrong
description:
This video was sponsored by Tiimo, the visual planning app: https://go.onelink.me/w6CP/tiimocalendar (available on Apple, Android and desktop)

The topic of autism in girls is highly searched for these days, and in 2019 I made a video called, "Autism Symptoms in Girls" , which has gone on to be the highest viewed video on this channel: https://youtu.be/ixRSb00BplM

But after much reflection I wanted to revisit this idea of "gendered autistic traits" and move away from the idea of female autism and male autism altogether.

I chatted with Purple Ella about this topic and we decided to do a mini collab where we both discuss this topic. Check out her video here:
https://youtu.be/P3ohpP5q3m0

Cordelia Fine books I recommend (Affiliate links):
Delusions of Gender (UK) https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3373/9781848312203
Delusions of Gender (US) https://bookshop.org/a/16677/9780393340242
Testosterone Rex (UK) https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3373/9781785783180
Testosterone Rex (US) https://bookshop.org/a/16677/9780393355482

A clarification about Maria Montessori - The Absorbent Mind (not her first book as I said in the video) does contain some quotes re: her eugenicist views, although her general educational philosophy does not promote this. I actually do really appreciate parts of the Montessori method, but I wanted to mention her views to make the point that it was not uncommon for people to hold them, even people who had otherwise decent thoughts about education.

title: Show Us Who You Are: Interview with ND author Elle McNicoll
description:
Show Us Who You Are is the second novel from award-winning neurodivergent author Elle McNicoll. Set in the future, it combines sci-fi concepts and neurodivergent representation, into an amazing story for middle grade readers (and beyond!).

If you like a story that's a cross between Black Mirror, Gillian Cross and arguing in an online autism group about person-first language... this one's for you!

Watch my interview with Elle about A Kind of Spark from last year: https://youtu.be/Cu8x_9k9Kqk

Affiliates links to purchase:
UK orders:
Show Us Who You Are: https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3373/9781913311131
A Kind of Spark: https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3373/9781913311056

US orders:
A Kind of Spark PREORDER: https://bookshop.org/a/16677/9780593374252

#ShowUsWhoYouAre #ElleMcNicoll

title: First trimester pregnancy update // Autistic and pregnant
description:
This video was sponsored by Tiimo, the visual planning app: https://go.onelink.me/w6CP/tiimocalendar (available on Apple, Android and desktop)

The first trimester of pregnancy is tough for everyone,  but being autistic adds an extra layer on top of that, so I thought I'd give an update from the comfort of week 15 (later by the time this was uploaded), to let you know what it was like for me, for both pregnancies, and comparing how it was before I knew I was autistic with my current pregnancy.

tags: ['autistic musician', 'beethoven', 'beethoven autistic', 'was beethoven autistic', 'historical figures with autism', 'yo samdy sam', 'yo samedy sam', 'yo sammy sam', 'autistic composers']
title: Was Beethoven autistic? (ft. the Piano Rogues)
description:
Check out the Piano Rogues talking about Ode to Joy here: https://youtu.be/4AOR6hgSyn4
(Plus our performance!)

Was Beethoven autistic? Since we'll never have the definitive answer, I thought I'd take you on a journey, figuring out how we might make a good guess as to whether a historical figure is on the spectrum, and what evidence there is in Beethoven's life that points that way.

A big thank you to Piano Rogues for approaching me for this collab, providing extensive research, arranging the piece for my guitar level and being a joy to collab with!

title: Autism and Witchcraft
description:
Join me on a festive discussion of the intersection of autism and witchcraft, featuring an interview with autistic witch Meg Rosenbriar, and much silliness from Sam.

Meg's Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/witchoftheshoreline/
Witch With Me: https://witchwithme.com/
WWM Insta: http://www.instagram.com/witch.with.me
WWM FB: http://www.facebook.com/groups/witchwithme
The Healing power of Witchcraft (UK affiliate link): https://amzn.to/2HP7S7m
The Healing Power of Witchcraft (US affiliate link): https://amzn.to/34JoqGD

More about witchcraft beliefs in Nigeria: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-50742414
Witchcraft and autism in Africa (upsetting read): https://www.afrik-news.com/article17924.html
Within the UK: https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/mar/01/accusations-witchcraft-pattern-child-abuse
Swedish study on autistic people's supernatural experiences: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/2153599X.2018.1548374

Beginner spells from Meg:
Spell 1 - Mother Earth: https://yosamdysam.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Spell-1-Mother-Earth.png
Spell 2 - Guilt Be Gone: https://yosamdysam.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Spell-2-Guilt-Be-Gone.png
Spell 3 - Happiness by the Jarful: https://yosamdysam.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Spell-3-Happiness-by-the-Jarful.png

title: Chatty, *almost at 50k celebration* Q&A
description:
Join me for an *actually* chilled out chat, which is just an opportunity to talk with you lovely lot and (somewhat prematurely) celebrate approaching 50k subs here on YouTube.

Hoping to answer lots of your questions! Leave them in the comments below if you want me to look at them in advance.

I did change the schedule for my monthly lives for a variety of reasons (mainly related to fitting in other videos), so they will no longer be last video of the month.

title: Autism, PTSD and Trauma: what's the connection?
description:
Autism, PTSD, c-PTSD, BPD - so many acronyms, so many diagnoses, that can all appear very similar to each other and often have overlapping traits and symptoms.

Join me on an exploration of the connection between autism and trauma.

Suggested videos:
What is Autism? https://youtu.be/kt1r-GlRkJg
Autism diagnosis criteria: explained https://youtu.be/1yva4RZW_s0
What do autistic people seem weird? https://youtu.be/YiGZdMgPU7s

tags: ['autistic masking', 'masking', 'coping strategies aspergers', 'emotional intelligence asd', 'paul micallef', 'autism in adults', 'aspergers from the inside emotional intelligence', 'female aspergers coping strategies', 'autistic masking and burnout', 'autistic masking definition']
title: Autistic Masking and Unmasking ft. @Aspergers from the Inside
description:
Autistic masking - a conversation between Yo Samdy Sam and Aspergers From the Inside

Join me as I talk to Paul Micallef who runs the amazing "Aspergers From The Inside" for a live discussion about masking - why we do it, what it looks like, whether we should #TakeTheMaskOff or whether it serves a purpose? How can we live authentically while still masking? How can we convince people that we're autistic when all they see is a version of us?

We will also be telling you about the upcoming "Autism Explained" summit, which Paul has organised and I will be one of the speakers. It is an online event, running over 5 days from 21st September 2020, which you can sign up for free at: https://autism-explained.teachable.com/?affcode=285883_-1xdeg5m

This live is scheduled at a slightly different time from usual due to the time difference between me and Paul, so I hope to see many of you there or on the replay! Set your reminders now, you won't want to miss this!

title: Autism and Job Interviews
description:
Autism and job interviews: is there a way for autistic people to learn to succeed at interview?

When you are autistic, job interviews can be as painful as the dating process, you are expected to know the rules, but no one will tell you what they are.

Luckily, there seems to be progress in terms of how employers view the value of neurodiversity within their teams, but also support that's available for autistic people.

I spoke to Emily Banks, founder of Stack Recruitment, about her organisation that aims to help autistic people find jobs and educate companies on how their interview and hiring process can be more accessible for autistic people.

Stack Recruitment are London-based but can serve employers and applicants within the UK: https://stackrecruitment.org/

Contact Emily: emily@stackrecruitment.org

RELATED VIDEOS:
Why do autistic people seem weird? https://youtu.be/YiGZdMgPU7s
Autism and work (LIVE) https://youtu.be/jZyjw6pCRn0

title: How I Manage My Week Using TIIMO ‚åö (App for ADHD and Autism)
description:
How do I plan my week?

Ever wonder how I manage my week as a mother, YouTuber, business owner and wife who also struggles with executive functioning (especially time management) due to autism and ADHD?

This is a #sponsored video in partnership with Tiimo, the smartwatch/mobile app for autistic and ADHD brains.

Find out more at: https://go.onelink.me/w6CP/tiimocalendar (available on Apple, Android and desktop)

How I time block (or how I calendar block as some people might call it) is with an app called Tiimo, which lets me micromanage my week in advance and then sends me notifications on my smartwatch to remind me to start AND stop each activity. The timer feature lets me easily see how much time I have left to complete each task, and when paired with a Smartwatch sends out small vibrations to keep me on track throughout the day and prevent me from getting distracted (well ok, most of the time).

I use this app in conjunction with a paper and digital planner, and I hope to cover my whole organisational system in a future video.

This was the first in a 3 part series on executive functioning, so please subscribe and click the notification bell if you want to stay up to date with future videos.

‚åö MORE EXECUTIVE FUNCTIONING VIDEOS: ‚åö
Ditch Your To-Do List: https://youtu.be/FTi3jdYEIZc
Reset Your Life After Summer: https://youtu.be/dHkbohd-BeQ
How To Plan Your Weekly Tasks To Avoid Overwhelm: https://youtu.be/Waopcht7cVw

title: I think I might be autistic: What now?
description:
I think I might be autistic! Help me, Sam!

If you think you might be autistic, you've watched a lot of videos on the topic, read articles, done online tests (like the AQ test, for example), it can be hard to know where to go from there.

I hope this video will guide you through the next steps and make life a bit easier for those of you going through this right now.

Adult Diagnosis: Is it worth it? https://youtu.be/SUJJ_7gMtDk

title: Autism at work
description:
This month's live: autism at work. A discussion of autism in the workplace, the obstacles that neurodivergent people face, not just in the interview process, but in continuing and thriving in a job.

With special guest Naomi Johnson, who works in the IT sector as a Neurodiversity Consultant.
Contact her here: naomi.johnson@spectrumcircle.co.uk
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/naomi-johnson-484209/

Studies mentioned: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28211841/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25891885/
https://www.autism.org.uk/get-involved/campaign/employment.aspx

title: A Kind of Spark: author interview (autistic children's book)
description:
A Kind of Spark is a middle grade novel written by autistic author Elle McNicoll, with an autistic protagonist, 11 year old Addie.

I talked to Elle about neurodiversity and inclusion in publishing, how witchcraft is used as a parallel to autism throughout the novel, and her experience of being an autistic author.

Pre-order now:
https://www.roundtablebooks.co.uk/bookshop/a-kind-of-spark-pre-order
https://blackwells.co.uk/bookshop/product/A-Kind-of-Spark-by-Elle-McNicoll-author/9781913311056
https://www.waterstones.com/book/a-kind-of-spark/elle-mcnicoll/9781913311056 (INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING)

Cover illustration by: https://www.instagram.com/kayaotic/

Follow Elle McNicoll:
Twitter: https://twitter.com/BooksandChokers
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/booksandchokers/

tags: ['Hyperlexia', 'early reading', 'precocious reading', 'yo samdy sam', 'hyperlexia 3']
title: Hyperlexia: my experience
description:
Hyperlexia is the precocious and self-taught ability to read, usually before the age of 4, and sometimes as early as 18 months - 2 years.

This is my experience of being an early reader (though undiagnosed), as well as my observations about my son, who is coming up to 3, and on track to read in a similar timeframe to me.

Autism and early reading don't always go together, but there is some overlap.

Please note: I am not an educational professional, and if you have concerns about your child, please ask one! These are my own experiences and reflections, about me and my child only.

tags: ['autism diagnosis criteria', 'DSM criteria for autism', 'dsm criteria for autism spectrum disorder', 'dsm 5 autism', 'dsm autism spectrum disorder', 'autism spectrum disorder diagnostic criteria', 'autism diagnosis', 'diagnostic criteria for asd', 'autism spectrum disorder dsm 5 criteria', 'self advocate']
title: Autism diagnosis criteria: explained (DSM-5)
description:
The autism diagnosis criteria are written for professional use and are therefore shrouded in mysterious and somewhat opaque language. In this video, I'm attempting to explain the DSM criteria for autism diagnosis (under the umbrella of Autism Spectrum Disorder) which is used in North America and parts of Europe (the ICD-11 is a more international version, but it is largely the same for the purposes of autism diagnosis)

To read the DSM-5 criteria for yourself:
https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/autism/hcp-dsm.html

Getting an adult diagnosis of autism: is it worth it? https://youtu.be/SUJJ_7gMtDk
Being autistic at uni: https://youtu.be/rBhmjFuJNpY

title: I'm not OK (but that's OK)
description:
Last Friday I was going to do a video on the DSM criteria for autism, but I felt this massive emotional block and I felt completely paralysed to take any action. title: Driving while autistic: my experience
description:
Driving while autistic (or learning to drive) can be filled with struggles for many people.

In this video I talk about
- My own experience learning to drive as an undiagnosed autistic adult (and eventually passing my test)
- The various skills needed to drive which might get overlooked as particular struggles for autistic people: motor skills, visuospatial differences, attention to detail (and why that might be a hindrance) and navigational skills.
- A few tips that might help

title: Do I have any autistic dating advice? // Q&A
description:
This week's video is just a casual, chatty Q&A for some light relief (and to give me a little break after doing 3 videos for World Autism Acceptance Week!).

It was filmed several weeks ago, which is why I look so carefree and relaxed. I receive questions on my Instagram mainly, so please go over there and follow me (Yo Samdy Sam) if you want to ask me any questions for the next one. Or comment down below!

1. How do you cope with appointments? (Doctors, hairdressers etc)
2. Have you ever had a minor meltdown while driving?
3. How much of a role does music play in your life?
4. Do you get professional support? What kind?
5. What is your favourite food?
6. What kind of (non-musical) sounds do you like?
7. How do you use emojis?
8. Why are some HSPs (highly sensitive people) autistic and some aren't?
9. Do you have any dating advice?

title: How to help autistic people - not just in April
description:
Sometimes it's hard to know exactly how to help autistic people in a practical way. It's a difficult question, and because autism is a spectrum and all autistic people have different needs, you might think it's too complicated that you don't want to risk getting it wrong.

This video hopes to give you some advice for how different people can provide help and support: partners, friends, family, co-workers, peers, bosses and managers.

All of my ideas are just suggestions, there is no substitute for opening an honest dialogue with the autistic person in your life and learning more about autism in general.

Autism acceptance is for life, not just for April!

Autism awareness & acceptance 2020 playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfWrZJcC_lTBYOsVdChcfeZtJbpdJv1n-

Recommended neurodiversity consultant: Naomi.johnson@spectrumcircle.co.uk

localizations.fr.title: Comment aider les personnes autistes - pas seulement en avril
localizations.fr.description:
Il est parfois difficile de savoir exactement comment aider les personnes autistes de mani√®re pratique. C'est une question difficile, et comme l'autisme est un spectre et que toutes les personnes autistes ont des besoins diff√©rents, vous pourriez penser que c'est trop compliqu√© pour ne pas risquer de vous tromper.

Cette vid√©o esp√®re vous donner quelques conseils sur la mani√®re dont diff√©rentes personnes peuvent aider et soutenir : partenaires, amis, famille, coll√®gues, pairs, patrons et responsables.

Toutes mes id√©es ne sont que des suggestions, rien ne remplace l'ouverture d'un dialogue honn√™te avec la personne autiste de votre vie et l'approfondissement des connaissances sur l'autisme en g√©n√©ral.

L'acceptation de l'autisme est pour la vie, pas seulement pour le mois d'avril!

Playlist 2020 de sensibilisation et d'acceptation de l'autisme : https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfWrZJcC_lTBYOsVdChcfeZtJbpdJv1n-

title: What AUTISTIC people wish you knew
description:
What autistic people wish you knew - 10 things we'd like you to know about autism.

This is part 2 of a mini-series I'm doing for World Autism Acceptance Week, which aims to educate, inform and raise awareness (and acceptance, obviously) of autistic people, especially how autism presents in adults.

My video on functioning labels and why "mild" autism doesn't really exist:
https://youtu.be/fD5jAwPlSDY

My video on masking and whether you can (or should) take the mask off:
https://youtu.be/t9COmZ2HwXY

My playlist for World Autism Acceptance Week 2020:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfWrZJcC_lTBYOsVdChcfeZtJbpdJv1n-

The communication study referenced:
https://www.utdallas.edu/news/health-medicine/autism-social-interactions-2020/

title: What is AUTISM? // Autism awareness and acceptance
description:
What is autism? What is it like to be autistic?

Autism spectrum condition (or autism spectrum disorder, depending on who you ask) is a neurological condition that affects 1-3% of the population, maybe more.

I made this video to help people understand what autism actually is, as there is so much misinformation and so many myths out there. In this video I talk about sensory sensitivities, social communication, stimming, executive functioning and special interests.

title: World Autism Day 2020: How to get involved
description:
World Autism Day 2020 is nearly upon us and whether you call it World Autism Awareness Week, World Autism Acceptance Week, we as a community are coming to together to celebrate and promote autistic acceptance.

In this video I explain how to get involved with the #RedInstead movement on April 1st, and the #AutisticGold "Coming out" day on April 2nd.

If you want to know why I DON'T want you to "Light It Up Blue", check out the video I made last year: https://youtu.be/Eg5ZORDwVzs

For more information check out these links:

Our Golden Moment: https://www.ourgoldenmoment.com/

title: Coping with change
description:
Links:

Katya's Ko-Fi: https://ko-fi.com/katyawoloshyn 
Sophie's art channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCkRPmBEqMuIFA_nnubiM0rw
Adulting Autistic: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCGQ78cJiMcJhMbpKhjunAxg
Adulting Autistic Podcast: https://open.spotify.com/episode/1Lgh7xcRwdpiTk0F5OMKBE?si=vCrLySMmRjuYM1peIirX7Q
ArdelleVision: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXXYDeJ3oHX37NjKMi_pgHg

These are unprecedented times and everyone is having to change their lives - quickly and drastically. How can we come together (virtually) and cope with these changes?

As well as talking very seriously about some of the things we can do, I'm hoping to lighten the mood with some silliness and entertainment this time. There are a couple of special guests lined up (not just my cats) and while it won't be the Royal Variety Show I hope it'll give us all some community, happiness and hope.

title: Noise cancelling earplugs: which are best?
description:
Noise cancelling earplugs reduce volume in crowded places, but can you still have a conversation? Is that even possible?

For many autistic people, sensory overload is the most distressing part of our condition, with noisy environments being more likely to send us into shutdown (or meltdown).

A good pair of noise reducing earplugs will greatly improve our (and other noise sensitive people's) quality of life, so I look at 4 types to see which I like the most for everyday use.

(DeepSleeps moldable silicone, mentioned briefly)

title: Aphantasia: a life with no mind's eye (interview)
description:
Aphantasia is a condition where people are unable to create mental pictures or imagine things in their "mind's eye". It is often (but not always) associated with neurodivergent (autistic, ADHD) individuals.

This week I am talking to Dianna Moylan, an aphantasiac, about her experience of life without mental pictures.

The Man Who Mistook His Wife For a Hat (Oliver Sachs):

title: Autistic MASKING: how do we do it and should we stop?
description:
For many autistic adults, masking is the reason why we ‚Äúdon‚Äôt look autistic‚Äù. But what is it, does everyone do it and how can it help us, actually?

In this video I take a look at some recent research on the topic which identified four categories of ‚Äúcompensatory strategies‚Äù, different ways in which autistic people obscure their true selves to fit in with friends, get a job or promotion, or just exist in the neurotypical world.

Why Autistic People Seem Weird (Uncanny Valley theory): https://youtu.be/YiGZdMgPU7s 
Why Autistic Women Seem Two-Faced: https://youtu.be/9lugR8NaPiM 

Study on masking (see Table 1 especially): https://molecularautism.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13229-019-0308-y

 @Aspergers from the Inside¬† video on taking off the mask: https://youtu.be/vPf9CLMG2Es 

Galaxy lamp UK link (similar, not identical): https://amzn.to/37UYh62

localizations.en-GB.title: Autistic MASKING: how do we do it and should we stop?
localizations.en-GB.description:
For many autistic adults, masking is the reason why we ‚Äúdon‚Äôt look autistic‚Äù. But what is it, does everyone do it and how can it help us, actually?

In this video I take a look at some recent research on the topic which identified four categories of ‚Äúcompensatory strategies‚Äù, different ways in which autistic people obscure their true selves to fit in with friends, get a job or promotion, or just exist in the neurotypical world.

Why Autistic People Seem Weird (Uncanny Valley theory): https://youtu.be/YiGZdMgPU7s 
Why Autistic Women Seem Two-Faced: https://youtu.be/9lugR8NaPiM 

Study on masking (see Table 1 especially): https://molecularautism.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13229-019-0308-y

 @Aspergers from the Inside¬† video on taking off the mask: https://youtu.be/vPf9CLMG2Es

title: More Autistic Headcanons! Elsa, Mr Bean and more...
description:
Autistic headcanons are characters that we, as autistic people, like to claim as "one of us". It's a bit of fun speculation that helps promote understanding of what autistic people can look like, as opposed to the stereotyping that often occurs if a character is officially labelled "autistic".

In this video I talk about 5 (or 6 for the pedants) characters that I strongly believe could be autistic.

My previous autistic headcanons video is here: https://youtu.be/_83wTaWZTME

tags: ['yo samdy sam', 'yo samedy sam', 'autism and religion', 'religion and autism', 'autism and religious belief', 'aspergers and religion', 'yo samdy sam stimming']
title: Autism, Religion and Belief
description:
Autism and religion are two rather controversial topics, but this is a neutral, sociological perspective of the relationship between the two.

I talk about my personal experiences of religion and why I am an atheist, the appeal of religion for autistic people (but also but it might not appeal), the historical role of clergy, and a few problematic ways in which religion could manipulate autistic people.

By the way, forgot to mention what my Masters degree was in: Religion in Contemporary Society!

Autistic Not Weird survey mentioned: https://autisticnotweird.com/2018survey/

tags: ['autistic motherhood', 'ditl autism', 'yo samdy sam', 'yo samedy sam']
title: Day in the Life // Autistic mother // Raw vlog DITL
description:
I decided to do a Day in the Life style video because a few people had requested vlog-style content, but also because I am struggling more and more with the day-to-day stress of motherhood, and teetering on the edge of autistic burnout. Videos like these are a little bit easier to film and edit.

This is a peek into my life, the day after a meltdown. Please be kind in the comments as I am vulnerable right now. I am not showing this to elicit sympathy or pity or attention. I simply wanted to show how it's not just the big things that can wear us down, it's death by a thousand papercuts of sensory overload, lack of rest, lack of a good social network, not enough alone time, constant changes in routine, that over weeks and months can build up inside and there's no clear way out.

üîÄAll my autism videos in one handy playlist üîÄ: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfWrZJcC_lTAJvhgia_UqpidfyNARkPCN

title: High or low functioning autism? Why functioning labels hurt us
description:
High or low functioning autism? Both are unhelpful terms

This video is all about high functioning autism (adult), and why I believe we need to stop calling autistic people high or low functioning.

I talk about how functioning labels came about, a little about Asperger‚Äôs syndrome and the DSM V change, and why functioning labels ultimately harm all autistic people.

As always, this is just my opinion, I don‚Äôt speak for anyone other than myself, but let‚Äôs try and keep it civil in the comments please! ;) 

Framing this argument as a battle between low functioning autism vs high functioning is unhelpful because a lot of the accommodations we might need end up being the same, even though our outward presentation may be different.

localizations.da.description:
H√∏jt- eller lavtfungerende autisme? Begge dele er begreber, der ikke hj√¶lper nogen.

Denne video handler om h√∏jtfungerende autisme (hos voksne) og om, hvorfor jeg mener, at vi skal holde op med at kalde autister for h√∏jt- eller lavtfungerende.

Jeg taler om, hvordan disse beskrivelser blev til, lidt om Aspergers og √¶ndringerne i DSM 5, og om hvordan funktionsbeskrivelserne i sidste ende skader alle autister.

Som altid er det MIN holdning, jeg taler ikke for andre end mig selv, s√• hold en god tone i kommentarerne, tak! ;-)

N√•r man fremstille dette som en kamp mellem de lavt- og h√∏jtfungerende autister, s√• er det til stor skade, fordi meget af den st√∏tte, som vi har brug for, i sidste ende er den samme, selvom vi ser meget forskellige ud.

title: Getting an adult autism diagnosis - is it worth it?
description:
Getting an adult autism diagnosis is fraught with uncertainty, and once you‚Äôve had your "lightbulb" moment that you think you might be autistic, the first thing you have to figure out is ‚Äúshould I get assessed for autism?‚Äù

There are many pros and cons to getting a late autism diagnosis, and while this video is not comprehensive, I talk about the various factors that might help you decide whether or not it‚Äôs worth pursuing an autism diagnosis in adulthood.

title: Gift Ideas for Autistic People
description:
What do autistic people like?

It can be hard to think of gift ideas for autistic people. We can seem picky, ungrateful or rude when it comes to gift receiving. I hope this guide is helpful in explaining a bit more about what we like (and what we don‚Äôt) while of course accepting that every autistic person is different!

Think of these gift ideas for adults with autism as inspiration rather than a declaration from the Grand High Autist that "all autistic people like these things".

If you want to buy the items, some of the links below (but not all) are affiliate links which means that I get a small commission at no extra cost to you. It helps support my channel and helps me make more content.

title: Autism Comorbities
description:
There are many conditions which are comorbid (frequently co-occurring) with autism: ADHD, dyslexia, dyspraxia, OCD, anxiety, depression, the list goes on. For this live stream we'll be discussing these from a non-medical, experiential standpoint. 

What is it like to have more than one condition? Does it make it harder to explain to people, or find understanding professionals?

title: Autistic Adult Takes the AQ (autistic quotient test) with¬†@IndieAndy
description:
Ever wondered how actually autistic people answer the AQ test (or autistic quotient test)? In this video, I talk through my own answers to the test.

This was a collab with Indie Andy, who also took the AQ test on his own channel. Check out his video right here:

https://youtu.be/BEx4nBQcKj0

This week, Indie Andy and I decided to both take the AQ (autism quotient) test to see how good it is at accurately identifying autistic traits. I personally have a lot of criticisms of the test and some of the questions. As you can see in the video, a lot of them are open to wild interpretation, and I think that this is potentially missing a lot of autistic people in the screening process because of the somewhat outdated stereotypes of autism it perpetuates.

(You can also take the AQ test online here: https://psychology-tools.com/test/autism-spectrum-quotient)

Interested to know what you guys think about the test as well!

‚òïIf you like my content and want to ‚Äútip‚Äù me, you can buy me a Ko-Fi here ‚òï: https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam 
Request a video here: https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam/commissions

This week, Indie Andy and I decided to both take the AQ (autism quotient) test to see how good it is at accurately identifying autistic traits. I personally have a lot of criticisms of the test and some of the questions. As you can see in the video, a lot of them are open to wild interpretation, and I think that this is potentially missing a lot of autistic people in the screening process because of the somewhat outdated stereotypes of autism it perpetuates.

(You can also take the AQ test online here: https://psychology-tools.com/test/autism-spectrum-quotient)

Interested to know what you guys think about the test as well!

title: Interview with Waltzing on Waves: a neurodivergent performer
description:
Pre-order Waltzing on Waves‚Äô debut album here: https://waltzingonwaves.bandcamp.com/

Listen on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCMUTZsKzHNWw613Ad6C2GZQ

Listen on Spotify: https://open.spotify.com/artist/6NBm8u09fMrshjhu4f2quW?si=KY0N-ch4TqSz2nRREuphLg

In this interview I talk to Jen who is a neurodivergent performer and songwriter who goes by the name Waltzing on Waves.

We talk songwriting from an autistic/ADHD perspective, the struggles that neurodivergent performers face, the process of writing the album and making a living off music in a digital world.

title: Self-care for autistic people
description:
Self-care is a sort of trendy buzzword at the moment, used by advertisers to sell "little luxuries" to consumers, but self-care has an importance to autistic people beyond bubble baths and face masks (although those are nice)

When everything in the world sometimes seem too much to us - too loud, too bright, too awful-smelling - what are the steps we can take to take care of ourselves?

- Why do we need to prioritise self-care?

- And how can we do that?

- What even counts as self-care?

title: HATE to do lists? It doesn't have to be that way
description:
"I HATE to do lists" ‚¨Ödoes this sound like you? I have struggled with using to-do lists my whole life, because I found it overwhelming, linear and non-visual, and all the tasks got jumbled up in my head.

Executive functioning difficulties are common to both autistic people and people with ADHD, but by adulthood we are expected to have learnt how to do it,  and are expected to have our lives in order.

As part of my general ambition to get organised and reduce stress around the chaos in my brain, I came across a series of tweets which helped me reframe my tasks and create a bit of peace of mind.

tags: ['could you be autistic', 'could you be autistic and not know', 'traits of high functioning autism', 'self advocate']
title: Could YOU be autistic? (and not know)
description:
Could you be autistic and not know? I, and many other autistic adults with a late diagnosis of autism, will tell you - YES!

The current model of autism diagnosis is predicated on the assumption that autism traits will make themselves seen in early childhood. In fact, it is often thought of as a childhood disorder. But the amount of late diagnosed autistic adults means that clearly this model is missing something and instead of an outside-in approach we need to start thinking about an inside-out approach - listening to the internal experiences of autistic people, rather than having neurotypical researchers describe what they think they see.

WATCH NEXT: Autism diagnosis criteria explained https://youtu.be/1yva4RZW_s0

If you think this describes you like no one has ever described you before - here are some further resources. Please note, relating to all these points DOES NOT mean you are definitely autistic - there are many other conditions that it could be, so please see a professional if you're concerned.

Autism Quotient (AQ) test:
https://psychology-tools.com/test/autism-spectrum-quotient

Women on the spectrum checklist
https://the-art-of-autism.com/females-and-aspergers-a-checklist/

Den fremherskende model for autismediagnosticering bygger p√• en formodning om, at autismetr√¶k vil vise sig i den tidlige barndom. Faktisk ses autisme ofte som en b√∏rne-lidelse. 

Men antallet af sent diagnosticerede voksne autister betyder, at det er klart, at denne model overser noget, og i stedet for en udefra-og-ind-tilgang, skal vi begynde at t√¶nke mere indefra-og-ud: vi skal lytte til de indre erfaringer, som autister har, i stedet for at lade neurotypiske forskere beskrive, hvad de tror, de ser.

Hvis du synes, at dette beskriver dig p√• en m√•de, som du ikke har oplevet f√∏r, s√• er der her nogle ressourcer, der kan f√∏re dig videre:

title: REAFFIRMATION: Coming to terms with autism - interview with Rees Finlay
description:
Reaffirmation: Coming to terms with autism by Rees Finlay now available (affiliate links):

UK link: https://amzn.to/2PoaOro
US link: https://amzn.to/2P1MBs9

See the Kickstarter here: http://kck.st/2lDge7d

"Reaffirmation: Coming to terms with an autism diagnosis" is a comic book/novella by author and illustrator Rees Finlay. In it he details his life around the time of his autism diagnosis through the use of impactful emotional drawings and sarcastic and self-deprecating humour.

In this video, I talk to Rees about his book, his autism diagnosis and his Kickstarter campaign.

If you‚Äôre interested in the book Rees mentioned, you can buy ‚ÄúNeuroTribes‚Äù here: https://amzn.to/314hizI (UK affiliate link)

title: Dating & Relationships on the spectrum
description:
What practical advice is there out there for dating when you are yourself autistic? This week's live chat will focus on the perilous world of dating, courtship, starting (or ending!) relationships when you are autistic yourself. Is it easier when your partner is also autistic? Is modern dating too awful to contemplate?

Be sure to bring funny anecdotes and I'll try and scrape the barrels of my memories for stories.

I may need wine for this one.
caption: false

tags: ['Demisexuality', 'demisexual', 'asexual spectrum', 'gray asexual spectrum', 'gray ace', 'demisexuality and autism', 'autism spectrum', 'autism and sexuality', 'alexithymia']
title: Demisexuality and AUTISM: is there a link?
description:
For my video on Alexithymia ü§î, click here: https://youtu.be/S3tD94tB6T4

Demisexual people have a very specific way of experiencing sexual attraction.

Demisexuality is basically when you don't feel sexual attraction to other people unless some sort of strong bond or emotional connection has been made. With the prefix ‚Äúdemi‚Äù meaning ‚Äúhalf‚Äù, you could think of it as halfway onto the asexual spectrum. They are often known as "gray ace".

This relates to autism in a variety of ways - sensory/touch, relating to other people and building meaningful relationships, and understanding others intentions.

#demisexual #demisexuality #autism

description: Join me for a discussion on the challenges of being a parent on the spectrum (with or without autistic children), what we can do to make our lives easier, and general thoughts of the autistic parenthood experience.

tags: ['How to tell your family you‚Äôre autistic', 'coming out of the autism closet', 'coming out autistic', 'explaining autism friends and family', 'q&a', 'autistic adult', 'yo samdy sam', 'autism spectrum', 'aspergers syndrome', 'adult adhd symptoms']
title: How to tell your family you're autistic // Q&A
description:
This week's video is a chatty sort of Q&A, largely because I'm trying hard to prevent burnout right now. I have some really exciting videos lined up so please keep an eye out for them over the next month!

What benefits have you been encountering from being open about your autism diagnosis, and how do you deal innerly with the negative ones?

Doesn't it scare you the idea of having a kid who has a high probability of being autistic?

How do you tell your friends and family that you are autistic?

Did you ever think you also have ADHD? There seems to be much overlap with executive function.

If you had a diagnosis before kids what would you have done to get ready for the overwhelm?

How did you end up in the Netherlands? Is your husband Dutch?

tags: ['autistic pregnancy', 'being pregnant and autistic', 'autistic pregnant', 'autistic girl pregnant', 'autistic daughter pregnant', 'my autistic daughter is pregnant', 'autism in women and girls', 'autism adult women', 'autism and pregnancy', 'autistic women', 'pregnant while autistic', 'autism and childbirth']
title: Autistic pregnancy: how I coped
description:
Autistic pregnancy: Being pregnant and autistic comes with a unique set of struggles, yet it seems like there is almost no information out there on how to deal with it. (There is also very little information out there on autism in women and girls which I hope to change with this channel)

In this video I share my autistic pregnancy journey, talking about the dreaded first trimester to pain relief, and dealing with the social side of pregnancy and the communication issues that arise with it.

Whether it's for you, your spouse or a family member, I hope you enjoy this video!

National Autistic Society hospital passport: https://www.autism.org.uk/about/health/hospital-passport.aspx

title: RESET your life after summer
description:
Do you struggle with how to reset your life after summer?

The summer holidays can be hard for those of us with executive functioning difficulties who thrive on route and predictability.

I've got some tips to follow to reset your life and get back on track for the new school year/season/upcoming few months.

Download my free household task planner HERE: https://www.subscribepage.com/yosamdysam

tags: ['Autism and food issues', 'autism and food', 'aspergers and food']
title: Autism and FOOD issues: my experience
description:
Autism and food issues often go hand in hand, and for me personally, my childhood was full of anxiety and stress about the food that I ate (or didn‚Äôt). As an undiagnosed autistic child, I thought of myself back then as ‚Äúfussy‚Äù, whereas now I can appreciate the sensory sensitivities and aversions to food texture that are common in autistic people, and reframe my past self as an autistic child with food aversions.

In this video, I‚Äôm discussing my food habits as a child (and an adult) and what I think the people around me could have done to help me eat a better diet at the time.

If you like my content, keep watching! Check out these links below:

title: Would an earlier diagnosis of autism have helped? // Q&A and 1000 subs thank you!
description:
Would an earlier diagnosis of autism have helped me?

This is such an interesting question and something that we can speculate endlessly about, so keep watching to find out what I think‚Ä¶

tags: ['Why do autistic people seem weird', 'why are autistic people weird', 'Yo Samdy Sam', 'why do autistic people freak you out', 'autism spectrum disorder', 'neurodiversity', 'uncanny valley', 'neurotypical behaviour', 'autistic traits', 'real life aspergers', 'emotional intelligence aspergers', 'emotional intelligence asd']
title: Why do autistic people seem weird?
description:
Why do autistic people seem weird to you? What is it about them and their behaviour that sets them apart from the neurotypical population, and makes them a target for bullies and narcissists?
---
‚òïIf you like my content and want to ‚Äútip‚Äù me, you can buy me a Ko-Fi here ‚òï: https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam 
üì∑My Instagram üì∑: https://www.instagram.com/yosamdysam/
üîÄIf you‚Äôre new to my channel, start HERE üîÄ: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfWrZJcC_lTAJvhgia_UqpidfyNARkPCN
---
My working theory is that it‚Äôs a combination of factors. Autistic people are very sensitive and constantly processing sensory stimuli. Secondly, many (mostly)neurotypical people make thin-slice judgements, that is snap judgements about whether a person is ‚Äúone of us‚Äù, within a matter of seconds.

Even autistic people who mask a lot can give away certain ‚Äútells‚Äù that they deviate from the norm, because you can get so far by masking and ‚Äúfaking normal‚Äù but at some point the mask will begin to slip.
---

tags: ['Being an autistic mother', 'autistic parenting', 'autistic motherhood', 'parenting while autistic', 'autistic adulthood', 'mental health', 'autism spectrum disorder', 'autism spectrum', 'high functioning autism', 'adult diagnosis autism', 'beeing an autistic mother', 'autistic mother', 'struggling with autism parent']
title: Being an AUTISTIC mother: what's it like?
description:
Being an autistic mother is hard, and not something that‚Äôs often discussed in the realm of parenting. In this video I talk about the difficulties I face, from sensory overload to difficulties socialising with other parents and the sheer exhaustion of keeping going.

Autistic motherhood is exhausting and isolating and especially when people think you have "high functioning autism", there can be a perception that you don't need any extra help or support. 

If you're an autistic mother, please don't be afraid to get support if you need it.

If you liked this video check out my video on Autism symptoms in GIRLS: https://youtu.be/ixRSb00BplM

tags: ['disneyland paris autism', 'autism family vlog', 'autism theme park', 'disneyland autism pass', 'is disneyland paris autism friendly']
title: Disneyland Paris with AUTISM: what's it like for autistic adults?
description:
Disneyland Paris with AUTISM: Being autistic at a theme park can be a very overwhelming experience. Disneyland Paris was the first theme park I've been to for years, and only because I learned that autistic people are entitled to Disney's Priority Card, which allows you to use the disabled entrance on rides and skip the (horrendously long) lines.

The measurements of the Priority Card are: 10 x 12.5cm
(Affiliate) link to a plastic card holder that would fit your card: https://amzn.to/2Ya1VsC
(Affiliate) link to the type of musicians earplugs I used: https://amzn.to/2Mdv27o
Neurodiversity lanyard: https://www.etsy.com/listing/623861804/neurodiversity-infinity-spectrum-lanyard

All my autism videos in one place: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfWrZJcC_lTAJvhgia_UqpidfyNARkPCN

tags: ["we're all on the spectrum", "we're all on the autism spectrum", "we're all a bit autistic", "everyone's autistic", 'mild autism spectrum disorder', 'are we all a bit autistic', 'adult diagnosis autism', "everyone's a little bit autistic", 'high functioning autism spectrum disorder', 'different types of autism spectrum disorders', 'autism spectrum disorder']
title: But we‚Äôre all on the spectrum somewhere!
description:
The myth that ‚Äúwe‚Äôre all on the spectrum somewhere‚Äù has to be one of the more pervasive autism myths, and everyone who has an adult diagnosis of autism (especially those diagnosed with so-called high functioning autism spectrum disorder) has likely encountered a version of this at some point.

That there are different types of autism spectrum disorders (or as I prefer to call it different ‚Äúcolour palettes‚Äù of autism) does not mean that everyone on the planet sits somewhere along a linear scale ranging from ‚Äúnot autistic‚Äù to ‚Äúextremely autistic‚Äù. It‚Äôs much more complicated than that.

Firstly, the autism spectrum is used to describe the variety of autistic experiences, not the experiences of neurotypicals who have a few autistic traits.

Secondly, It is not a linear spectrum from ‚Äúmild‚Äù to ‚Äúsevere‚Äù autism. Every autistic person has a combination of traits that is unique to them, many of which can be equally debilitating in different ways. Functioning labels help neither the ‚Äúhigh functioning‚Äù autistic who is presumed to be fine nor the ‚Äúlow functioning‚Äù autistic who is presumed incompetent.

If you don‚Äôt want to miss a video, sign up to receive new videos straight to your e-mail, every week: https://www.subscribepage.com/yosamdysam

tags: ['person with autism or autistic person', 'person first language autism', 'autistic person or person with autism', 'identity first language', 'person first language', 'neurodiversity', 'autism spectrum condition', 'disability language etiquette', 'what not to say to autistic people', 'aspergers syndrome', 'autism spectrum']
title: Why many autistic people DON'T like person-first language
description:
Have you ever wondered whether it‚Äôs better to say ‚Äúperson with autism or autistic person‚Äù? Today I‚Äôm giving my personal opinion on the matter (with the absolute expectation that other autistic people will disagree with me, natch).

Person first language has its origins in AIDS activism and has spread throughout advocacy groups for chronic health conditions and various disabilities.

Person first language for autism has come largely from organisations and autism parents, rather than the autistic community themselves. Autism, by definition of being a childhood/developmental disorder, has the unique position of having (possibly neurotypical) parents thrown into the mix. This leads to many becoming ‚Äúspokespeople‚Äù for their children, but I wonder if they are projecting their personal prejudices about autism onto the identity their child has.

Feel free to disagree with me, but let‚Äôs keep it civil in the comments please!

If you want to read more on this topic, see this excellent article from The Aspergian: https://theaspergian.com/2019/04/19/person-first/

Last weekend, I had a huge amount of new subscribers and YouTube marked them all as spam... and deleted them. If you don't want this to happen to you, you are very welcome to sign up to my e-mail list here:

https://www.subscribepage.com/yosamdysam

I will e-mail you once a week with my latest videos and some interesting links from around the web (maybe, if I can get my act together!)

localizations.da.title: Om hvorfor mange autister IKKE bryder sig om "mennesket-f√∏rst"sprogbrugen
localizations.da.description:
Har du t√¶nkt over, om det er bedre at sige "menneske med autisme" eller "autist"? I dag udtrykker jeg min personlige holdning til sagen (med den klare forventning, at andre autister vil v√¶re helt uenige, naturligvis).

Mennesket-f√∏rst-sprogbrugen stammer fra AIDS-aktivismen og har bredt sig til andre fortaler-grupper for kroniske helbredstilstande og visse handicaps.

Mennesket-f√∏rst-sprogbrugen omkring autisme kommer is√¶r fra organisationer og autisme-for√¶ldre (for√¶ldre til b√∏rn med autisme) og ikke fra de ber√∏rte selv. Autisme, der pr. definition er en tilstand, som man er f√∏dt med, har alts√• den s√¶rstilling, at (m√•ske neurotypiske) for√¶ldre er med i ligningen. Det f√∏rer til, at mange af dem fungerer som "talspersoner" for deres b√∏rn, men jeg overvejer, om ikke de overf√∏rer deres egne fordomme om autisme p√• deres barns identitet.

Du m√• meget gerne v√¶re uenig, men lad os holde en god tone i kommentarerne!

Hvis du vil l√¶se mere om dette emne, s√• kig p√• denne fremragende artikel fra The Aspergian: https://theaspergian.com/2019/04/19/person-first/

I sidste uge fik jeg en masse nye abonnenter. YouTube troede, at det var spam - og slettede dem! Hvis du vil undg√• at blive slettet, s√• er du meget velkommen til at abonnere p√• mit nyhedsbrev: https://www.subscribepage.com/yosamdysam

Jeg vil skrive ca. en gang om ugen om mine nyeste videoer, og m√•ske - hvis jeg kan tage mig sammen - gode links fra rundt om p√• internettet.

tags: ['how to plan your weekly tasks', 'executive functioning strategies', 'managing executive functioning', 'executive dysfunction adults', 'adult adhd', 'adult autism', 'autism symptoms', 'coping skills', 'organisational skills', 'organization hacks', 'organization tips', 'adult adhd symptoms', 'adult autism diagnosis', 'adult adhd treatment']
title: How to plan your weekly tasks to avoid overwhelm
description:
Get your FREE download here: https://www.subscribepage.com/yosamdysam

Despite putting so much effort into TRYING, knowing how to plan your weekly tasks when you have adhd or autism can sometimes leave us adrift in a sea of (well-meaning) advice.

I can‚Äôt count the number of cleaning schedules I‚Äôve pinned on Pinterest or systems that seem to only work for these superhuman housekeeping machines.

Executive dysfunction in adults with autism and ADHD is easily dismissed as lazyness from the outside by people who don‚Äôt understand what it‚Äôs like to live with our minds.

So finding executive functioning strategies that work can be difficult and involve a lot of trial and error.

I‚Äôve developed this template to help me manage my weekly tasks and it works because:

- It‚Äôs flexible, so the system doesn‚Äôt fall apart if I miss a day‚Ä¶ or two
- It allows for co-operation and gamification (if you and your partner/housemates are competitive like that)
- You can easily see when a task was last completed without having to visually keep an eye on the state of things (something I used to do as my primary strategy)

Let me know if you have a strategy, and how it works for you.

title: Autism symptoms in GIRLS
description:
Autism symptoms in girls can be quite different from the stereotypical presentation we see in the media (and which was taught to me as a Psychology undergraduate 10 years ago).

Autism in women and girls is far more likely to be diagnosed later in life, but we still struggle just as much as men on the spectrum, and struggling through when undiagnosed can be very detrimental to our mental health.

Watch this video for more information on:
- Stims
- Social skills/communication
- Executive functioning
- Special interests
- Sensory issues
- Co-morbid/ misdiagnosed mental health conditions

Video from invisible i which first made me think I might be autistic: https://youtu.be/5wKb5TUX49U

Suggested videos:
What is Autism? https://youtu.be/kt1r-GlRkJg
Autism diagnosis criteria: explained https://youtu.be/1yva4RZW_s0
What do autistic people seem weird? https://youtu.be/YiGZdMgPU7s

To learn more about my YouTube channel memberships, click the "JOIN" button or visit: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCk5aCrQAppGZ8atiOpgYZ1A/join

If you like my content and just want to buy me a virtual coffee ‚òï to support my work, or commission a video on a topic of your choice (see the "commissions" tab for details), you can buy me a Ko-Fi here: https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam

Autism symptoms in GIRLS

Autism symptoms in girls can be quite different from the stereotypical presentation we see in the media (and which was taught to me as a Psychology undergraduate 10 years ago).

Autism in women is far more likely to be diagnosed later in life, but we still struggle just as much as men on the spectrum, and struggling through when undiagnosed can be very detrimental to our mental health.

Watch this video for more information on:
- Stims
- Social skills/communication
- Executive functioning
- Special interests
- Sensory issues
- Co-morbid/ misdiagnosed mental health conditions

title: Life after autism diagnosis: update
description:
Life after autism diagnosis - how has it affected me? A diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder (particularly as an adult) is a huge life adjustment - when you start to look back on your life after years of labelling yourself as one thing (oversensitive, shy, weird, quirky) and finally realising you are indeed all of those things, but more importantly, you are AUTISTIC.

Women are typically diagnosed much later than men, which means that many, if not most of us have gone through life being ‚Äúcorrected‚Äù by those around us, and blaming ourselves for our perceived shortcomings.

tags: ['reading my old diary', 'reading my diary', 'reading diary', 'autistic diaries', 'actually autistic', 'neurodiversity', 'teenage mental health', 'undiagnosed autism', 'growing up with undiagnosed autism', 'undiagnosed autism spectrum disorder', 'reading my teenage diary', 'reading my teenage diaries', 'autistic adult']
title: Reading my teenage diaries - as an autistic adult #actuallyautistic
description:
Reading my teenage diaries was quite the illuminating exercise. I thought it would be a fun idea for a video to look back at a randomly selected diary from my teenage years (when I was living with undiagnosed autism, among other things) and see if I could detect any signs of autism that were missed back then.

Oh boy, there were plenty! I kept diaries from about the age of 11, and believe me, the video would have been a LOT longer had I included everything! Growing up with undiagnosed autism clearly took its toll on my mental health at the time, and although I am much happier today, my wish is that no one else ever has to go through what I did.

Trigger warning: frank discussion of teenage mental health, suicidal thoughts, disordered eating, and more.

Making this video was actually quite hard - to film and to edit, but I found it rather therapeutic in the end, to release all the pain that 16 year old Sam had bottled up inside.

What I didn't expect was that it often felt like I was reading the diary of a completely different person (which was a relief I suppose!) and instead of cringing at myself, I just felt compassion for the person I used to be.

---

Credits where credit's due:

Greta Sting Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com)
Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 3.0 License
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/

This video idea was partly inspired by Mortified: http://getmortified.com/

tags: ['autistic at university', 'Being autistic at university', 'autistic at univeristy', 'being undiagnosed autistic at university', 'being autistic at college', 'being undiagnosed autistic at college', 'autism and university', 'higher education autism', "what's it like being autistic at uni", "what's it like being autistic at university", "what's it like being autistic at college", 'autistic advocacy', "what's it like having aspergers at university", 'starting university autistic', 'autism spectrum disorder']
title: Being (undiagnosed!) AUTISTIC at university
description:
What is it like being (undiagnosed) autistic at university? In this video I tell you about my experiences in higher education - the good, the bad, and the ugly.

An important part of autistic advocacy is sharing our experiences, especially so that undiagnosed autistic people can pursue a diagnosis (if they feel that would be helpful).

My experiences at uni were definitely not what I expected, and this part of my life with undiagnosed autism was particularly tough for a variety of reasons.

I'd love to hear what your uni experiences were like - feel free to share them in  the comments below!

tags: ['autistic people two-faced', 'Why autistic women seem two-faced', 'autistic mental health', 'autistic masking', 'social skills autism women', 'social masking autism', 'autism in women', 'autistic two-faced']
title: Why autistic people seem two-faced
description:
Do you have a friend or a family member who is autistic and often seems like they are being fake or two-faced? Autistic people can seem two-faced when they engage in what is known as "autistic masking"

For further thoughts on the subject please have a look at my article for The Aspergian here: https://theaspergian.com/2019/05/20/why-autistic-women-seem-two-faced/

Many autistic women I have spoken to have agreed that we have often been perceived to be two-faced or even manipulative. For us, this can be totally baffling when our intention was never to offend anyone, let alone end friendships over a misunderstanding.

In today‚Äôs video I explore why I think that is, the concept of autistic masking, people pleasing, and how we can encourage greater communication between autistic and non-autistic people.

title: Alexithymia // What it's like to not know how you feel #alexithymia
description:
Alexithymia describes an inability to recognise or name your own emotions. Coming from the Greek to mean literally "no words for emotions", alexithymia is strongly related to autism (it is estimated over half of autistic people also have alexithymia)

Being in touch with your own emotions is vital to building friendships and relationships. I believe a lot of the social aspects I struggle with due to autism can be partly attributed to alexithymia as well.

Here's the test I took, interested to see how other people do, so let me know in the comments down below:

https://www.alexithymia.us/alexithymia-questionnaire-online-test

For further thoughts on the subject: https://theaspergian.com/2019/05/13/alexithymia-and-autism-what-its-like-to-not-know-how-you-feel/

‚òïIf you like my content and want to ‚Äútip‚Äù me, you can buy me a Ko-Fi here ‚òï: https://ko-fi.com/yosamdysam

tags: ['Recovering from an autistic meltdown', 'Recovering from a meltdown', 'Autistic meltdown adult', 'autism meltdown adult', 'autistic meltdown women', 'aspergers meltdowns only at home', 'autism meltdown', 'autism spectrum', 'autism awareness', 'autistic meltdown']
title: Recovering from an autistic meltdown
description:
What's it like having a meltdown as a newly diagnosed autistic adult? Recovering from a meltdown comes with a lot of strange emotions and feelings that I am still processing several days after. I am trying to rest and be kind to myself but I wanted to get a video out this week, so I hope you find it interesting/illuminating/helpful/supportive/whatever.

If you're an #actuallyautistic adult, let me know in the comments below what your meltdowns are like, how often you have them, and how you recover.

tags: ['Second hand thrift haul', 'haulternative', 'sustainable fashion', 'slow fashion', 'charity shop haul', 'second hand haul', 'thrift haul', 'try-on', 'spring thrift haul', 'spring thrift haul and try on', 'try on haul', 'summer thrift haul', 'spring summer haul 2019']
title: HUGE second hand thrift haul & try-on #haulternative
description:
I recently challenged myself to buy only second hand or sustainable fashion brands, and I found so much great Spring/Summer stuff from the thrift store that I just had to do a #haulternative haul video.

Second hand thrift hauls are all the fun of a regular fast fashion haul without the devastating impact on the environment (and those pesky human rights violations).

I bought these items from a regular thriftstore (Snuffelmug), a consignment shop, and online from Marktplaats.

I got a bit confused on the video about pricing, but I spent roughly:

‚Ç¨40-45 on the thrift store
‚Ç¨65 at the consignment store
‚Ç¨60 on Marktplaats

So I probably spent around ‚Ç¨170 (US$192/¬£147) total on what is almost a capsule wardrobe in itself.

#haulternative #ss19 #secondhandthrifthaul #slowfashion

title: My favourite autistic characters (autistic headcanon)
description:
In this video I explore my top five favourite autistic characters from film, tv and literature. All opinions are my own and just a part of my personal autistic headcanon - they may or may not have actually been intended to be autistic.

There‚Äôs a dearth of autistic representation in the media, so let‚Äôs claim these characters (and add your favourite autistic character below in the comments!)

tags: ['Don‚Äôt light it up blue', 'actually autistic', 'autism pride', 'acceptance not awareness', 'neurodiversity', 'light it up gold for autism', 'world autism awareness day 2019', 'autism speaks', 'light it up blue', 'high functioning autism', 'go red instead', 'neuroatypical', 'autism awareness', 'world autism awareness day', 'autism spectrum disorder', 'autism speaks (organization)']
title: Please DON‚ÄôT light it up blue for Autism Awareness Day #actuallyautistic #autismpride
description:
World Autism Awareness Day is big bucks these days, and organisations, businesses and even government buildings around the world now ‚Äúlight it up blue‚Äù for autism awareness. While pretty blue buildings and monuments are undoubtedly pleasing from a sensory perspective, this year I urge you to reconsider your support of their campaign. Here‚Äôs why.

We are already ‚Äúaware‚Äù of autism - what autistic people need from society is more widespread education about our neurological differences, and willingness from the neurotypical majority to accommodate us in situations they may never have considered before as ‚Äúunfriendly‚Äù to autistic people.
 
No amount of fundraising, puzzle piece t-shirts or baking blue cupcakes is going to change the fact that we live in a world designed at almost every turn to accommodate neurotypicals, with very little thought to improving the lives of actually autistic people, especially autistic adults.

For more information on why ABA therapy is harmful, please visit:
https://theaspergian.com/2019/03/28/invisible-abuse-aba-and-the-things-only-autistic-people-can-see/
caption: false

tags: ['why i quit social media', 'quit social media', 'social media', 'anti social media', 'quit instagram', 'quit instagram for a month', 'quit facebook', 'mindfulness meditation', 'clear your head', 'mental health', 'self care']
title: Slowing down (and quitting social media) for better mental health
description:
I decided to quit Instagram and significantly reduce my time spent on Facebook, as I found it was affecting my brain in a really negative way.

Quitting social media gave me the chance to clear my head, and meditate on my life.

All that mental chatter that had built up as I was bombarded by news articles, photos of this and that, knowledge of what that person I met that one time had for lunch today‚Ä¶ that eventually disappeared and allowed me to live my life in a more mindful way.

Facebook is much harder to quit for good, but I'm taking it one day at a time. I do believe we get addicted to the little rushes of dopamine that Facebook provides us with, but I am learning that the longer I'm away from it, the less attractive it is.

-----

Cinematic (Sting) by Twin Musicom is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution licence (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/)
Artist: http://www.twinmusicom.org/
